Synergies of surface-interface multiple active sites over Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported nickel catalysts for enhancing the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole Yaowen Zhang Investigation Methodology Writing – original draft Guoli Fan Investigation Formal analysis Yanjun Lin Writing – original draft Visualization ⁎ Lan Yang Conceptualization Feng Li Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Currently, the catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of oxygen-containing compounds derived from biomass to highly valuable chemicals or hydrocarbon bio-fuels is attracting more and more attention. Concerning the design and synthesis of high-performance supported metal catalysts for HDO, the efficient deposition/immobilization of active metal species on supports, as well as the construction of the favorable properties of supports, is quite necessary. In this work, we fabricated series of aluminum-zirconium oxide solid solution supported Ni-based catalysts by a simple surfactant-assisted homogeneous coprecipitation and applied them in the HDO of anisole. Various structural characterizations showed that surface-interface properties of Ni-based catalysts (i.e., surface acidity, defective structures, and metal-support interactions) could be finely tuned by adjusting the amount of Al introduced into Al-Zr oxide solid solutions, thus profoundly governing their catalytic HDO activities. It was demonstrated that the introduction of an appropriate amount of Al could not only enhance surface acidity and promote the formation of defective Zr-O v -Al structures (O v : oxygen vacancy) but also facilitate the generation of interfacial Niδ+ species bound to the support. Over the Ni-based catalyst bearing an Al2O3:ZrO2 mass ratio of 5:2, a high cyclohexane yield of ∼77.4% was attained at 230 °C and 1.0 MPa initial hydrogen pressure. The high catalytic HDO efficiency was revealed to be correlated with the catalytic synergy between Ni0 and adjacent interfacial Niδ+ species, together with the promotion of neighboring defective oxygen vacancies and acidic sites, which contributed to the enhanced activation of the methoxy group in anisole and reaction intermediate and thus greatly improved HDO activity. The present findings offer a new and promising guidance for constructing high-performance metal-based catalysts via a rational surface-interface engineering. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Nickel catalysts Al-Zr oxide solid solution Surface and interface Multiple active sites Hydrodeoxygenation 1 Introduction Presently, as an ideal, renewable, and environmentally friendly carbon resource for manufacturing bio-fuels, biomass is attracting more and more attention. Due to the high oxygen content in lignin-derived bio-oils composed of phenols, aldehydes, furans, esters, and ketones, there exist several undesirable disadvantages for practical application as direct transportation fuels, such as high viscosity, strong acidity, poor chemical stability, and low calorific value [1,2]. To utilize bio-oils as the potential alternative to complement unsustainable fossil fuels, their downstream upgrading is becoming a prerequisite. Among all chemical upgrading methods, catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) processing is regarded as a highly efficient route to remove oxygen-containing groups in bio-oils [3]. Typically, methoxybenzene (anisole) is widely explored as a lignin-derived prototype model molecule for the upgrading of biomass. During the anisole HDO, demethoxylation reaction, which is identified as one of the most important processes, may finally result in the prominent production of deoxygenated cyclohexane or benzene. In this regard, constructing high-performance catalysts has become a decisive factor controlling HDO efficiency. On the other hand, the direct deoxygenation of lignin derivatives is an important research goal to maintain the valuable aromatic features inherited from the lignins. Recently, some ultra-selective catalysts, such as Ni-Fe [4], MoO x [5], Pt-WO x [6], Pt-NbO x [7], and alkali-doped FeC [8] catalysts, have been reported for HDO of lignin derivatives without ring hydrogenation to selectively produce aromatics (BTX: benzene, toluene, and xylene). For instance, selective cleavage of C-O bonds was realized in the HDO of m-cresol without ring hydrogenation to toluene over the MoO x catalyst, where coordinatively unsaturated sites played a vital role in facilitating the direct C-O cleavage [5]. And, for bifunctional Pt-WO x and Pt-NbO x catalysts [6,7], m-cresol absorbed on surface oxygen vacancies or unsaturated Nb cations could undergo direct hydrogenolysis to toluene. Previously, supported transition metal sulfides [9,10] and noble metals [11–13] were widely studied owing to their high catalytic HDO performance for lignin derivatives. However, some issues, such as serious leaching of active components [9], the contamination of products by sulfur [14], and the formation of carbonaceous deposits [15], as well as the sintering of metal particles at high reaction temperatures, easily take place during the HDO process, thereby leading to poor stability and difficult reusability of catalysts. Therefore, a variety of supported non-noble metal HDO catalysts have been developed. Among them, especially, Ni-based catalysts are intensively investigated [16–18], because of their lower cost and better hydrogenation activity for both olefinic and aromatic groups, and higher selectivity to deoxygenated compounds, compared with Co- and Fe-based catalysts [18]. In addition to active metal sites facilitating the activation of reactants (e.g., hydrogen molecule and lignin derivatives), catalyst supports may significantly impact the performance of metal catalysts in the HDO process [19,20]. Specifically, it is generally accepted that acidic supports may favor the HDO of lignin derivatives, due to the promotional effect of acidic sites on the adsorption and activation of reactants. For example, besides acidic zeolites (i.e., HBeta, HZSM-5) [21–23], metal oxides [24,25], such as ZrO2, CeO2, and Al2O3, have been widely used as HDO catalyst supports. What’s more, binary metal oxides, such as SiO2-Al2O3, and CeO2-ZrO2 [26,27] may exhibit better functions to improve activity, selectivity, and stability of resulting catalysts. Moreover, the metal-support interactions often play a vital role in governing the HDO performance of catalysts. In most cases, however, traditional preparation methods for supported metal catalysts, such as coprecipitation, incipient-wetness impregnation, and colloidal deposition [28–31], make it difficult to obtain uniformly dispersed metal NPs with strong metal-support interactions (SMSIs). Therefore, for promising supported metal catalysts, advanced design and construction of the favorable synergy between active metal sites and surface-interface structures is a prerequisite for boosting their catalytic HDO performance. In this contribution, series of Al-Zr oxide solid solutions supported nickel-based catalysts for the HDO of anisole were fabricated via a facile cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB)-assisted homogeneous coprecipitation approach ( Scheme 1), which could realize highly homogeneous precipitation of Ni2+ ions with Zr4+ and Al3+ ions involved in the binary oxide support. Comprehensive structural characterizations revealed the effects of the introduction of Al on the metal-support interactions, surface acidity, and defective structures with consequences on catalytic HDO performance of catalysts. It was demonstrated that the appropriate introduction of Al into the Al-Zr oxide solid solution could not only generate new surface acidic and defective Zr-O v -Al (O v : oxygen vacancy) sites but also enhance the metal-support interactions through the generation of interfacial Niδ+ sites bound to the support. As-fabricated Ni catalyst bearing an Al2O3:ZrO2 mass ratio of 5:2 exhibited a superior HDO performance with a high cyclohexane yield of ∼77.4%. It was disclosed that the high catalytic HDO performance of the present Ni-based catalyst was correlated with the catalytic synergy between Ni0 and adjacent interfacial Niδ+ species, together with the promotional effects of neighboring acidic sites and defective oxygen vacancies. Up to now, no such Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported Ni-based catalysts for highly efficient anisole HDO was reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Different Ni-based catalysts with the Ni loading of ~30 wt% and the Al2O3/(Al2O3 +ZrO2) mass ratio of x:7 (x = 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7) were fabricated by a surfactant-assisted coprecipitation method. Firstly, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) (1.5 g) was put into deionized water (100 mL) under vigorous sonification for 30 min to gain a solution. Then, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and Al(NO3)3·9H2O, and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in the above surfactant solution, followed by titration with 1.4 M aqueous Na2CO3 solution until pH = 9. The formed suspension was aged for 12 h at 60 °C, centrifuged, washed by 50 °C ethanol-water mixture solvent (1:1 v/v) for more than 5 times, and heated at 500 °C under air atmosphere for 4 h to obtain NiO-x precursors. At last, NiO-x sample was reduced at 600 °C in a mixture gas of H2 and Ar for 2 h at a raising rate of 5 °C min−1 to get Ni-x samples. Before characterizations and reactions, reduced samples were sealed into sample tubes in a glove box charged with inert N2 gas. 2.2 Sample characterizations The structural characterization details including X-ray diffraction (XRD), content analysis of Ni, Al, and Zr metal elements, low-temperature nitrogen adsorption-desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), X-ray absorption structure (XAS) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO chemisorption, Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine and anisole, temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD), temperature programmed decomposition (TPDE), and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) are provided in Supplementary material. 2.3 HDO test of anisole In a typical anisole HDO run, anisole (4.5 mmol), n-decane (15 mL), and the catalyst (0.04 g) were added into the 100 mL autoclave reactor. Then, the sealed reactor was charged with pure nitrogen for 5 times, and pressurized to a certain hydrogen pressure. Subsequently, when the reactants were heated to a set reaction temperature (i.e., 230 °C), the HDO reaction began by a mechanical stirrer with a speed of 800 rpm. This moment was regarded as the zero moment of reaction. After a certain reaction time, the reactor was rapidly cooled down by an ice bath within a short time. In addition, the reactor was cooled down immediately in an ice bath when reaching the set reaction temperature (i.e., 230 °C) to get the benchmark results. The reaction was repeated three times. Finally, the products were analyzed using gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) and the DB-WAX ultra-inert capillary column, along with dodecane as an external standard. Anisole conversion of and product selectivities were calculated by subtracting the corresponding benchmark results, and the carbon balances based on the reactants with a six-member-ring structure were more than 97.0% in all cases. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis During the synthesis of different NiO-x catalyst precursors via the CTAB-assisted coprecipitation, Ni2+, Zr4+, and Al3+ cations could closely contact with surfactant vesicles at the end of its long carbon chain, thereby giving rise to homogeneous coprecipitation of metal ions and thus forming uniformly integrated Ni-containing ternary metal oxide precursors. To study the reducibility of different NiO-x precursors and interactions between Ni species and the Al-Zr oxide matrix, H2-TPR characterization was implemented. As displayed in Fig. 1A, NiO-0 sample shows a reduction peak at around 503 °C and a small shoulder peak at 410 °C, which are associated with ionic Ni species in bulk NiO and surface highly dispersed NiO species [32,33], respectively. Compared with NiO-0, other Ni-based samples show higher reduction temperatures. When Al ions are introduced, the above reduction peaks shift towards 597 and 450 °C, respectively. With the further increase in the Al content, they slightly shift to higher temperatures, mirroring the more difficult reduction of Ni2+ species. In each case, another small and broad reduction above 700 °C is assignable to the reduction of spinels containing Ni. The above results indicate the enhanced interaction between Ni species and the Al-Zr oxide matrix with increasing Al content. Fig. 1B displays XRD patterns of Ni-x samples. For Ni-0, a diffraction of (111) crystal plane for fcc metallic Ni is clearly discerned at 2θ of about 44.4°, in addition to several diffractions related to tetragonal ZrO2 phase (t-ZrO2). Generally, monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) is stable at room temperature [34]. However, m-ZrO2 is easily transferred into t-ZrO2 at high temperatures. Interestingly, it was reported the presence of oxygen vacancies could stabilize the structure of t-ZrO2 at room temperature in Cu/ZrO2 catalyst [35]. Also, other two (200) and (220) peaks of metallic Ni are detected in Al-containing Ni samples and enhanced with decreasing Zr content. Noticeably, the introduction of Al3+ ions may cause the serious broadening of (101), and (110) diffractions related to t-ZrO2 in the cases of Ni-1 and Ni-3, and even the disappearance of the ZrO2 phase diffractions in the Ni-5 sample, which mainly originates from the dramatic lattice contraction of the ZrO2 unit cell caused by the penetrating of Al3+ ions with smaller ionic radius (0.53 Å) than Zr4+ ions (0.72 Å) into the ZrO2 lattice. This phenomenon clearly illustrates the formation of Al-Zr oxide solid solutions in Ni-1, Ni-3, and Ni-5 samples. As for Zr-free Ni-7, no well-defined diffractions assigned to the crystalline Al2O3 phase are detected, owing to the formation of amorphous alumina support. According to the (111) line broadening for metallic Ni phase, the average crystalline size of Ni particles (8.4–9.0 nm) calculated by the Scherrer formula is almost the same among all Ni-based samples ( Table 1), indicating that the present synthesis approach is favorable for uniform dispersion of Ni nanoparticles (NPs) on the supports. According to N2 adsorption-desorption experiments (Fig. S1), the specific surface area of Ni samples increases gradually as the Al content increases and reaches a maximum of 90 m2/g in the case of Ni-5 (Table 1). For Ni-7, the decreased surface area is owing to the formation of the amorphous alumina matrix. Fig. 2a and Fig. S2 display TEM images of different reduced Ni-x samples. For Ni-0, some large particles are aggregated together on the surface. In the cases of Al-containing Ni samples, large quantities of particles with the particle size of 5–8 nm are well distributed over the surface with unclear metal-support interfaces, suggestive of strengthened metal-support interactions. Meanwhile, it is seen that, besides the agglomeration of Ni NPs, the size of Ni NPs in the Ni-7 is slightly larger than those in other samples, probably originating from its lower specific surface. HRTEM observation further reveals the fine microstructure of Ni-5 sample with the observable lattice fringes for Ni (111) crystal plane of 0.204 nm (Fig. 2b). The surface compositions of representative Ni-5 were further observed by HAADF-STEM characterization with element EDX mappings (Fig. 2c-g). It is observed that bright small Ni particles uniformly distribute over the Al-Zr oxide matrix, and Al and Zr species are in close contact with the Ni species, thereby strongly stabilizing Ni NPs on the Al-Zr oxide solid solution support and resulting in strong metal-support interactions. XPS analysis was performed to identify the surface electronic structures of elements on Ni-x samples. During XPS measurements, reduced samples were transferred into XPS sample chambers in a glove box to prevent the oxidation of surface metallic Ni0 species. To eliminate the interference of possible residual carbon derived from CTAB in Ni-x samples on XPS results, TPDE experiment of NiO-5 sample under Ar atmosphere was conducted. It was found that no any TCD signal was detected in the temperature range of 50–900 ℃ (Fig. S3), indicating that no residual CTAB exists in reduced Ni-x samples. In the fine Ni 2p3/2 region ( Fig. 3A), the fitted peak at about 852.7 eV is associated with metallic Ni0 species [36,37], and other two signals around 854.2 and 855.9 eV are associated with Niδ+ species strongly bound to the oxide matrix through the interfacial Niδ+-O-Zr (or Al)-like structure and Ni2+ species in Ni-containing spinels (e.g., NiAl2O4) [38], respectively. Meanwhile, in the fine Ni 2p1/2 region, Ni0, Niδ+, and Ni2+ signals also are found at about 869.9, 871.6, and 873.7 eV, respectively (Fig. 3A). It is noted that the Niδ+ fraction in total Ni species gradually increases from about 0.17–0.26 with increasing Al2O3/(Al2O3 +ZrO2) mass ratio from 0:7–5:7 (Table 1), indicating the enhanced interfacial interactions between Ni species and the Al-Zr oxide solid solution matrix. In the case of Ni-7, the surface Niδ+ fraction decreases to about 0.22. In reduced Ni-based samples, the existence of a significant amount of Ni2+ species is due to the incomplete reduction of cationic Ni species during synthesis. The XPS of Zr 3d region for samples were analyzed by deconvoluting into two pairs of doublets (Fig. 3B), where a doublet centered at ca. 182.1 and 184.5 eV can be assigned to Zr 3d 5/2 and Zr 3d 3/2 peaks for Zr4+ species, and another smaller doublet centered at about 181.3 and 183.7 eV are related to Zr3+ species [39,40]. The presence of a small amount of Zr3+ species may be the reduction of partial Zr4+ species during reduction treatment of Ni-based precursors. And, as displayed in Fig. 3B and C, XPS peaks of Zr4+ and Al3+ species all positively shift to higher binding energies with the gradual addition of Al. It suggests that interfacial Niδ+-O-Al or Niδ+-O-Zr -like structures can exist in Ni-x samples. In the O 1 s spectra of Ni-0 (Fig. 3D), three fitted peaks at 529.8, 531.4, and 532.9 eV are related to the lattice oxygen in the ZrO2 (OI), O2- and O- species adsorbed on oxygen vacancies (OII), and absorbed carbonate ions (OIII) [41,42], respectively. For Al-free Ni-0, t-ZrO2 support itself can provide surface oxygen vacancies. With the introduction of Al, the crystalline structure of t-ZrO2 can be destroyed, thereby leading to the dramatically reduced OII/O ratio for Ni-1 (Table 1), indicative of the decreased amount of surface oxygen vacancies. As the Al content is further increased, Al-Zr solid solution can be formed due to the incorporation of Al3+ cations into the structure of ZrO2, along with a positive shift in the binding energy of O species, which results in the formation of more oxygen vacancies and thus the increased OII/O ratio. For Ni-7, oxygen vacancies can be formed in the amorphous Al2O3 support. Among all Al-containing samples, Ni-5 possesses the highest surface OII fraction of about 0.34. It implies that the replacement of Zr4+ by Al3+ ions may generate a new type of surface defective sites like Zr-O v -Al structure (O v : oxygen vacancy) in the Al-Zr oxide solid solution, different from the defective structure in the pure ZrO2. And, the positive shift in the binding energies of Zr, Al, and O species with the increasing Al content is related to the formation of defective oxygen vacancies. Similar phenomenon also is found in the previously reported ZrO2-Al2O3 supported metal catalyst system [43,44]. It is inferred that such generated defective Zr-O v -Al structures might benefit the anisole HDO process by the methoxy adsorption and activation at oxygen vacancies, thus leading to the easy occurrence of the breakage of Cring−O bond in anisole. Further, Raman spectra were attained to explore the local environment of Ni species in reduced Ni-based samples (Fig. S4). For Ni-0, three broad characteristic Raman peaks for the t-ZrO2 phase appear at about 145, 258, and 624 cm−1, respectively [45,46]. In addition to the weakened vibration peaks of the t-ZrO2 phase at 145 and 258 cm−1, Ni-3 presents a broad peak centered at 582 cm−1, which stems from the generation of the new Al-O-Zr bond. In this case, the incorporation of a small amount of Al3+ into ZrO2-like oxide might lead to the decreased M-O vibration frequency. In the case of Ni-5, a peak appearing at the lower frequency of about 543 cm−1 is related to the longitudinal optical (LO) mode of Ni-O-Al structure [47], due to the doping of more Al3+ ions. This result further confirms the presence of strong interactions between nickel and the Al-Zr oxide solid solution, thereby resulting in the generation of more interfacial Niδ+-O-Al structures. The ex situ XAS characterization was carried out to gain the local structure of Ni atoms in supported Ni-based samples ( Fig. 4A). The XANES spectra of supported Ni-based samples display a white line intensity at the Ni K-edge, which is similar to that of nickel foil but not that of NiO sample. In addition, all samples depict the same pre-edge feature as that of Ni foil at around 8334 eV. It indicates that Ni species exist mainly in the form of Ni0 species, in addition to a small amount of Ni2+ species. Further, the corresponding Fourier-transform EXAFS spectra reveal a similar local geometric structure of Ni atoms in Ni-x samples to that in Ni foil. The k3-weighted EXAFS oscillations in R-space and k-space for Ni edge were presented in Fig. 4B and Fig. S5, respectively, and the fitted data for EXAFS are summarized in Table S1, based on the fitted curve (Fig. S6). In each case, the existence of metallic Ni0 species is dominant. Meanwhile, the Ni-Ni coordination number gradually decreases from 8.9 to 6.8 with increasing Al content, indicative of the formation of more metallic Ni nanoclusters in the low coordination state. Such coordinatively unsaturated metallic atoms are believed to be beneficial to the dissociation of molecular hydrogen during hydrogenation processes. H2-TPD was performed to identify the ability of dissociating hydrogen for Ni-x samples ( Fig. 5A). In all cases, a small low-temperature desorption peak centered at around 100 °C is attributed to surface hydrogen weakly bound to Ni0 sites. For Al-containing Ni-based samples, the following three desorption peaks in the range of 120–450 °C are associated with the hydrogen strongly bound to Ni0 sites [48–50]. In the above cases, dissociated H species are considered to exist in the form of nickel hydrides (Ni-H) [51]. At the same time, the hydrogen spillover also occurs above 450 °C in all cases. As summarized in Table 1, quantitative H2-TPD results show that the amount of chemisorbed hydrogen first increases gradually with increasing Al content from Ni-0 to Ni-5 and then inversely declines. This phenomenon should result from the formation of coordinatively unsaturated Ni0 sites with the low Ni-Ni coordination number (as proven by the above EXAFS results), thus promoting the dissociation of molecular hydrogen. Especially, Ni-5 affords a higher amount of chemisorbed hydrogen, thus leading to the formation of more Ni-H species. Previously, it was reported that nickel hydrides formed on or in metallic Ni particles could play a crucial role in the HDO reaction process [51,52], because of the function of such nickel hydrides serving as indispensable intermediates in the hydrogenation reaction [53]. To identify the surface acidity of Ni-x samples, NH3-TPD experiments were conducted. As displayed in Fig. 5B, three desorption regions in the ranges of 50–200, 200–600, and 600–900 °C are assignable to weak acidic sites (WAS), medium-strength acidic sites (MSAS), and strong acidic sites (SAS), respectively. Quantified results summarized in Table S2 depict that the amount of total acidic sites increases gradually with the Al content and then inversely decreases in the case of Ni-7. Especially, Ni-5 possesses the highest amount of total acidic sites, as well as weak or medium-strength acidic sites. In these cases, newly formed acidic sites should be associated with Al-O-Zr or Al-O pairs. Further, FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorption were collected to identify the types and strength of acidic sites (Fig. S7). Specifically, in the cases of Ni-3, Ni-5, and Ni-7, in addition to two broad bands (1590 and 1576 cm−1) related to H-bonding adsorbed (HB) and physically adsorbed (PS) pyridine, a strong band centered at 1442–1447 cm−1 is related to the adsorbed pyridine on Lewis acidic (LA) sites [54,55]; meanwhile, a broad band at 1603–1608 cm−1 corresponds to pyridine adsorbed on strong LA sites [56]. Ni-5 shows obvious blue-shifts of the above two bands related to LA sites compared with other samples, indicative of the improved strength of surface acidic sites. In all cases, no characteristic band for adsorbed pyridine on Brønsted acidic sites (1540 cm−1) can be detected (Fig. S7). It is speculated that LA sites formed on Ni-based samples may serve as active sites to adsorb and activate the C-O bond during the HDO of anisole. 3.2 Catalytic HDO performance In the HDO process of anisole, it was found that using a stirring speed of 600 rpm or above could eliminate external mass transfer limitations in all cases. Meanwhile, for Ni-x catalyst system, Weisz-Prater numbers all are far below 0.15, mirroring that internal mass transfer limitations can be neglected under the present reaction conditions [57,58]. Also, in each case, when the temperatures reached the set reaction temperatures, hydrogen pressures were always higher than initial hydrogen pressures before heating (Table S3), mainly due to the increased vapor pressures of reactants and the solvent at higher reaction temperatures. However, under the same reaction conditions, the difference in the hydrogen pressures over different Ni-x catalysts was not significant. Consequently, Fig. 6A compares the product distributions over supported Ni-based catalysts in the HDO of anisole at 230 °C after a reaction time of 5 min. Here, major products are cyclohexane (CHA) and methoxycyclohexane (MCHA), while small amounts of benzene (BEN) and cyclohexanol (COL) can be formed. It is noted that the activity and product selectivities differ among Ni-based catalysts. Over the Ni-0, MCHA with high selectivity of 68.4% is dominant, along with the formation of a quite small amount of completely deoxygenated CHA. Apparently, Ni-5 is more active than other Ni catalysts, with a higher CHA selectivity of ∼ 50.4%, indicative of the facile occurrence of demethoxylation. Further, HDO experiments were performed by varying the amount of catalyst dosage to achieve the difference in product selectivities over different Ni-based catalysts at similar conversions of ∼ 15% at 230 °C (Fig. 6B). Note that product selectivities differ among Ni-based catalysts. Over the Ni-0, MCHA with a high selectivity of 66.9% is formed, along with the production of a quite small amount of CHA, demonstrating that the demethoxylation process is suppressed. Apparently, despite a smaller amount of catalyst dosage, Ni-5 affords a higher CHA selectivity of ∼ 45.1% than other Al-containing Ni-based catalysts, indicative of the more facile occurrence of demethoxylation. Further, as the reaction time is prolonged, the CHA selectivity increases but the MCHA selectivity gradually decreases over the Ni-5 (Fig. 6C). It suggests that anisole might be first ring-hydrogenated to form MCHA, followed by a demethoxylation process to obtain CHA. Meanwhile, a small amount of benzene is generated at the initial reaction stage, demonstrating the occurrence of the direct breakage of the Cring−OCH3 bond in anisole. After reaction of 3.0 h, Ni-5 attains a high yield of CHA (77.4%) at a complete conversion (Fig. 6C, Table S4). In addition, methanol in gas and liquid phases and methane in gas phase were detected, indicative of the occurrence of the demethoxylation and demethylation reactions in the HDO of anisole, due to the cleavage of Cring-OCH3 and CringO-CH3 bonds. No formaldehyde and CO were produced. As shown in Table S4, the methanol/methane molar ratio of 2.04 over the Ni-5 catalyst confirmed the preference of cleavage of Cring-OCH3 bond over CringO-CH3 bond. To determine the intrinsic catalytic activity of Ni-x catalysts, the turnover frequency (TOF) for anisole conversion was determined according to the moles of anisole converted per mole exposed Ni0 sites (determined by the CO chemisorption) per unit time after 5 min (Fig. 6D). As we know, CO chemisorption method is widely used to determine the density of surface metal sites over Ni-based catalysts [47,59–61]. During H2-TPD characterizations, however, Ni-H species formed exist both on the surface/subsurface of metal particles and in bulk metal particles [62]. Moreover, in our case, metal oxides may significantly cover the surface of Ni particles. Correspondingly, the fraction of exposed metallic Ni0 sites is much smaller than that of bulk Ni0 atoms. As a result, CO chemisorption method is suitable to determine the density of surface exposed Ni0 sites. It is noted that the TOF values for Al-containing Ni-x catalysts are larger than that for Ni-0 (2041 h−1). Especially, Ni-5 achieves a much higher TOF value of 4180 h−1. Such a gap in the TOF value among Ni catalysts implies that surface Ni0 species are not the only active sites, and other active sites on catalysts might significantly govern the HDO process to a large extent. Cyclohexane is an important chemical intermediate to produce drop-in alternative bio-fuels from lignin resource [63]. Correspondingly, the catalytic HDO of lignin derivatives (i.e., anisole, m-cresol, and guaiacol) to cyclohexane has been explored extensively [64]. For instance, to date, various non-noble Ni-based catalysts are studied for the HDO of anisole to cyclohexane [60,61,65–68]. In some cases of supported Ni-based catalysts [59,63,64], however, harsh reaction conditions, such as high temperatures (≥290 °C) or high initial hydrogen pressures (≥ 6.0 MPa), are needed. Therefore, the development of high-performance Ni-based HDO catalysts is of great importance. In the present Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported Ni-based catalyst system, high-yield CHA can be obtained at 230 °C and initial 1.0 MPa hydrogen pressure for 3.0 h. Especially, compared to other previously reported Ni-based ones (Table S5), our present developed Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported Ni-based catalysts can efficiently catalyze the HDO of anisole to cyclohexane at relatively lower temperature and initial hydrogen pressure, which can be ascribed to the synergy between surface-interface multiple active sites. Further, as presented in Fig. 7A, higher reaction temperatures favor the formation of the benzene over the Ni-5, probably due to a higher energy barrier for the demethoxylation than that for the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring. In addition, the aromatic ring hydrogenation more easily takes place at higher initial hydrogen pressures (Fig. 7B), which should originate from higher concentrations of active hydrogen species formed on metallic Ni0 sites induced by higher hydrogen pressures. Therefore, as described in previous reports [13,66,69–74], two main different reaction pathways may occur in the present HDO process (Fig. 7C): (1) the direct demethoxylation and following aromatic carbon-ring hydrogenation; (2) the ring hydrogenation and following demethoxylation. Meanwhile, the demethylation of MCHA intermediate can form COL, and then further occurrence of dehydroxylation results in the production of CHA. It has been proposed that the main reactions in the HDO of anisole over metal-based catalysts with excellent hydrogenation activity are the aromatic-ring hydrogenation to form MCHA and following demethoxylation of MCHA to CHA [66,70,71]. In addition, the direct demethoxylation of anisole can occur over some selective catalysts [72–74]. In order to verify the reaction pathway over present Ni-based catalysts, HDO reactions of MCHA and COL intermediates were conducted. As shown in Fig. S8A, over Ni-based catalysts, two CHA and COL products are formed in the HDO of MCHA, suggestive of the occurrence of the demethoxylation/demethylation of MCHA intermediate to produce CHA and COL, as well as the dehydroxylation of COL. When COL was utilized as the substrate, only CHA was formed over all Ni-based catalysts (Fig. S8B). Especially, Ni-5 catalyst affords a higher yield of CHA than other Ni-based catalysts, indicative of the stronger dehydroxylation ability. Generally, hydrogenation/dehydrogenation of the ring is fast. Since benzene hydrogenation is an exothermic reaction, high reaction temperature can promote the ring hydrogenation, thus leading to the reduced yield of benzene with the temperature elevated from 190 to 230 °C (Fig. 7A). However, higher reaction temperature (>230 °C) inversely benefits the dehydrogenation of CHA to form benzene (Fig. 7A). Therefore, it demonstrates that the thermodynamic equilibrium between the hydrogenation of benzene and the dehydrogenation of CHA may reach at 230 °C. Besides, Ni-5 appears stable after five successive runs (Fig. S9). The anisole conversion and CHA selectivity is decreased by about 3.1% and 4.6% after five cycles, respectively, probably due to the loss of the catalyst in the catalyst recovery procedure. In the present Ni-based catalyst system, the presence of abundant oxophilic sites (i.e., acidic sites, defective structures) and interfacial Niδ+ sites might allow the easy desorption of deoxygenated products, probably inhibiting the deactivation of catalysts to a large extent. In addition, methoxyphenol (guaiacol) is usually utilized as another lignin-derived model molecule for HDO research. Therefore, the HDO of guaiacol also was conducted over Ni-x catalysts (Fig. S10). Noticeably, over the Ni-5 catalyst, a higher CHA selectivity can be attained at about 15% conversion. Moreover, Ni-5 catalyst affords a CHA yield of ~58% at a complete conversion, which is slightly lower than that in the HDO of anisole. The above results illustrate that our present Ni-x catalysts are effective for the HDO of lignin-based derivatives with oxygen-containing groups (i.e., methoxy group, hydroxyl group). 3.3 Reaction mechanism of the anisole HDO To gain insight into the behaviors of anisole adsorption and activation on catalysts, in situ FT-IR spectra of anisole adsorption on two representative Ni-based catalysts were recorded ( Fig. 8). The ν(CCring) bands appear at approximately 1586/1596 and 1495 cm−1 for Ni-1 and Ni-5 at 25 °C, respectively, while the ν(C-OCH3) bands for monodentate and bidentate anisole adsorbed are observed at 1291/1295 and 1246/1250 cm−1 [75,76], respectively. Compared to those for Ni-5, the adsorption bands of anisole for Ni-1 are much weaker and slightly lower in the wavenumber, probably owing to the much lower BET specific surface area, as well as the formation of less amounts of surface acidic sites, oxygen vacancies, and interfacial Niδ+ species responsible for anisole adsorption and activation in the case of Ni-1, thereby leading to a much lower TOF value over the Ni-1 catalyst. Meanwhile, compared to those for Ni-1, the ν(C-O) bands for Ni-5 are dramatically reduced with increasing desorption temperature, despite remaining strong absorption bands related to benzene ring. It implies the easy occurrence of the demethoxylation in anisole adsorbed on the Ni-5 catalyst. As demonstrated in the above catalytic experimental results, both the conversion and the product distributions differ among present Ni-based catalysts with similar metal loading. Concerning the change in the HDO performance over Ni-x catalysts, the underlying mechanism for the respective roles of surface acidity, defects, and interfacial structures needs to be unveiled. On the one side, one can note that the change in the conversion after 5 min is well consistent with the change in the surface concentration of metallic Ni sites (Table 1). This is because more exposed metallic Ni sites can favor the generation of nickel hydride during the HDO process. As expected, the change of the initial conversion rate of anisole as a function of the amount of nickel hydride presents an approximately linear correlation ( Fig. 9A), confirming that nickel hydride species formed on catalysts may significantly promote the HDO process. However, the lower dispersion of Ni species for Ni-0 sample (lower amount of CO chemisorption) may be ascribed to its much low surface area of Ni-0, which is due to the high crystallinity of t-ZrO2 support, thereby leading to the lower catalytic HDO activity. On the other side, since the dissociation of dihydrogen usually happens on metallic Ni0 sites, the formation rates of deoxygenated products may correlate with adsorption sites for anisole adjacent to Ni0 sites. To quantitatively obtain the structure–performance relationship, the deoxygenation rate for benzene and CHA formation as a function of the amount of surface acidic sites, defective concentration (i.e., surface OII fraction), and the fraction of interfacial Niδ+ species were correlated. First, the deoxygenation rate and the amount of total acidic sites present an approximately linear correlation on Ni-based catalysts (Fig. 9B). This result demonstrates that surface Lewis acidic sites may benefit the adsorption and activation of methoxy and hydroxyl groups. Second, the demethoxylation ability of Ni-based catalysts related to oxygen vacancies was explored (Fig. 9C). Notably, except for Ni-0, the deoxygenation rate presents a linearly increasing trend with increasing surface OII fraction. It demonstrates that defective oxygen vacancies should promote the demethoxylation of anisole and MCHA intermediate. In this case, the stronger interplay of the oxygen atom of anisole and intermediate with oxophilic defective sites represented by Zr-O v -Al structures may decrease the energy barrier of the C–O cleavage, thereby facilitating the demethoxylation or hydrogenolysis of hydroxyl group through the C-O cleavage. Third, the deoxygenation rate has a good linear relationship with the Niδ+ fraction (Fig. 9D), mirroring that the demethoxylation process can be promoted by interfacial Niδ+ species. In the present Ni-based catalyst system, the enhanced metal-support interactions can greatly facilitate the generation of interfacial Niδ+ species. In this regard, Niδ+ species adjacent to metallic Ni0 sites can act as electron acceptors to facilitate the adsorption of the oxygen atom of methoxy group in anisole and MCHA intermediate in the vicinity of Ni0 sites, which is beneficial to the activation of the methoxy group. Therefore, surface acidic sites, defective oxygen vacancies, and interfacial Niδ+ species on the Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported Ni catalysts serving as adsorption sites for reactant and intermediates containing −OCH3 and −OH groups can actively participate in the HDO reaction network, thus boosting their catalytic HDO activity. Correspondingly, Ni-5 presented the best catalytic efficiency for the production of cyclohexane due to the synergies of surface-interface multiple active sites. According to the structural characterizations and catalytic HDO experiments, a mechanism of catalytic HDO of anisole over present Ni-based catalysts is schematically illustrated in Scheme 2. During the HDO process, Ni-H species formed on catalysts are responsible for the improvement of hydrogenation activity, and surface-interface multiple active sites (i.e., acidic sites, defective sites, and interfacial Niδ+ sites) can benefit the adsorption and activation of anisole and reaction intermediates. Specifically, Ni0-Niδ+ synergy with the promotion of neighboring defective oxygen vacancies can facilitate the direct demethoxylation of anisole to produce benzene. In parallel, anisole is readily hydrogenated to MCHA with the help of Ni-H species and surface acidic sites. Subsequently, MCHA intermediate can go through direct demethoxylation to form CHA. In addition, the dehydroxylation of COL obtained from the demethylation of MCHA can occur to generate CHA product. Therefore, a favorable catalytic Ni0-Niδ+ synergy, together with the promotional effect of neighboring surface acidic and defective sites, should substantially contribute to the improved catalytic HDO activity of Ni-5 catalyst. 4 Conclusions To summarize, we developed series of Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported nickel-based catalysts via a surfactant-assisted homogeneous coprecipitation approach. The introduction of Al into the Al-Zr oxide solid solution could generate Niδ+ species at the metal-support interface, together with new acidic sites and defective oxygen vacancies. All applied Ni-based catalysts were active and could catalyze the demethoxylation process in the HDO of anisole. Especially, the catalyst bearing an Al2O3/(Al2O3 +ZrO2) mass ratio of 5:7 afforded a high CHA yield of ∼77.4%, along with a much higher TOF value of 4180 h−1 than those for single metal oxide-supported Ni catalysts. Comprehensive structural characterizations and catalytic experiments demonstrated that a catalytic synergy between Ni0 and interfacial Niδ+ species, together with the promotional effect of neighboring acidic and defective sites, could substantially contribute to the activation of reactants (i.e., H2, anisole, and intermediates), thereby resulting in the easy occurrence of demethoxylation process and thus boosting the HDO of anisole. Moreover, the strong metal-support interactions induced by the formation of the interfacial Niδ+ sites could endow the catalyst with good reusability and stability. With the viewpoints of the academic and industrial prospects, the present study provides an advantageous approach for designing new and promising non-noble metal HDO catalysts to upgrade lignin-derived compounds. coredata.dc:description: Currently, the catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of oxygen-containing compounds derived from biomass to highly valuable chemicals or hydrocarbon bio-fuels is attracting more and more attention. Concerning the design and synthesis of high-performance supported metal catalysts for HDO, the efficient deposition/immobilization of active metal species on supports, as well as the construction of the favorable properties of supports, is quite necessary. In this work, we fabricated series of aluminum-zirconium oxide solid solution supported Ni-based catalysts by a simple surfactant-assisted homogeneous coprecipitation and applied them in the HDO of anisole. Various structural characterizations showed that surface-interface properties of Ni-based catalysts (i.e., surface acidity, defective structures, and metal-support interactions) could be finely tuned by adjusting the amount of Al introduced into Al-Zr oxide solid solutions, thus profoundly governing their catalytic HDO activities. It was demonstrated that the introduction of an appropriate amount of Al could not only enhance surface acidity and promote the formation of defective Zr-O v -Al structures (O v : oxygen vacancy) but also facilitate the generation of interfacial Niδ+ species bound to the support. Over the Ni-based catalyst bearing an Al2O3:ZrO2 mass ratio of 5:2, a high cyclohexane yield of ∼77.4% was attained at 230 °C and 1.0 MPa initial hydrogen pressure. The high catalytic HDO efficiency was revealed to be correlated with the catalytic synergy between Ni0 and adjacent interfacial Niδ+ species, together with the promotion of neighboring defective oxygen vacancies and acidic sites, which contributed to the enhanced activation of the methoxy group in anisole and reaction intermediate and thus greatly improved HDO activity. The present findings offer a new and promising guidance for constructing high-performance metal-based catalysts via a rational surface-interface engineering.
coredata.dc:title: Synergies of surface-interface multiple active sites over Al-Zr oxide solid solution supported nickel catalysts for enhancing the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole
